ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Solid overview of seminal work in Chemistry. Often feels disjoint but probably good to know.
I learned a bit about chemistry concepts but most of it I taught to myself.
This class helped me understand basics in chemistry. It helped me learn how to take responsibility for my learning, and how to teach myself how to solve different types of problems.
I learned the foundations of chemistry.

I genuinely struggled to learn anything from this class. I feel that the concepts on the examinations were so distinctly different from what was actually being shown in class, and the PSETS also polar opposites in comparison to the class material. Therefore, the skills I learned were from what I felt was teaching myself from the class textbook in a toxic learning environment.
I learned to prioritize the styles of learning that worked best for me
How to study for exams, how to think critically about chemistry.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
- Covers a lot of content without making any of it too difficult
- Broad nature allows you to explore what aspects of chemistry you find interesting
Weakenesses:
- Formulaic and doesn't feel like it builds towards anything (I have no idea what I will do with any of this knowledge)
- Generally seems like tests are much more difficult than anything presented in lecture. Be prepared to learn a lot on your own - fortunately there are lots of great resources online.
It could be improved with another professor and a slower pace

The course itself was good. The curriculum was a good introduction to general chemistry, and tied ideas together well. However, Dr. G was the weakness of this course. Material was not sufficiently taught, and it felt like we were hardly covering the necessary topics even though we were consistently behind schedule. The efficiency and method of teaching of this class were the main weaknesses, and the class was much harder than it needed to be because of this. The information itself was not too complex, but it was taught in a way that made it much more difficult.

Strengths: the lectures were well organized and offered room for questions. The demos also helped me better understand the material 
Weaknesses: I wish more examples of questions were brought up in class
I was in Dr. G's small class and he often moved too quickly saying things like "this should be easy" when it was actually very difficult for most students. This made many of us feel stupid.

I took the small section of this class and I thought the biggest fault was the instruction. After every examination we were told that he was disappointed in us, he called us out in class negatively, and many things of the sort. During tests, we were told we cant ask questions about the questions even if it is for clarification (and yes there were typos that confused the concepts behind the questions), and for the same class (the larger section) students were given note sheets with information they should know for the exam and we were not given the same. This felt unfair, and as if we were being robbed as we all had to work harder for our grades. As for the strengths, though there was poor instruction behind it as well, the practice problems given in discussion had great content. The psets could also help as they had good content, though it was dissimilar to the concepts we were covering in class.
I thought that the course was too focused on online assignments and that the lectures werent very effective.

Strengths: very engaging 
weakness: none

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Potentially. If someone wanted a very brief overview of the field as a whole, maybe credit/d/fail it. Otherwise, it very much seems like something of a premed weed out course, and the preoccupation with performance makes for a less-than-pleasant learning experience at times.
No I would not. The course material is hard but doable except the professor does not know how to explain concepts in a way that beginners will understand.

I absolutely would not recommend this course to another student. General chemistry is not too bad in terms of material, but I would never recommend taking it with Dr. G. The class was taught horribly, and he was consistently demeaning to students who didn't understand topics immediately. General chemistry is a good science class to take, and for those who need to take it I'm sure with another professor it would not be that bad. But don't enroll in Dr. G's section.
It is a hard class, so I wouldnt recommend unless you need it for your major or for your pre-med requirements.
General Chem yes. Dr. G's section definitely not.

My answer to the question above is more or less an explanation of my issues with this course, but no I wouldnt ever recommend the small section of the course by any means. It was posed as increased resources and a more 1-on-1 experience, but out of all of my instructors I felt most disconnected with him. It made me feel distaste toward the subject of chemistry which I cared for initially, and I also feel less prepared than my large lecture classmates whom I will be joining in the coming semester.
Only if required.
Yes, very engaging and I learned a lot!
